sect1.title: Keyboards

sect2.title: Keyboard Types
sect2.para: Some GOK keyboards are specified in xml, and some are created dynamically while GOK is running.

sect1.para: You can create new keyboards or modify existing ones by editing keyboard xml files.

note.para: Keyboard XML Format: There is no formal schema or DTD for the GOK keyboard XML format. An examination of the existing *.kbd.in files is the best way to learn the format. A good place to start is to try and modify launcher.kbd.in to launch your favorite application.

sect3.title: Main Keyboard
sect3.para: The GOK - Main screen is comprised of the following seven buttons:

sect4.title: Word Completion
sect4.para: The top spaces above the function keys are used for word completion displays.

sect4.title: Modifier Latching and Locking
sect4.para: "Latching" or "locking" of modifier keys, such as Shift and Ctrl, may be performed by enabling Sticky Keys. To enable Sticky Keys use the Keyboard accessibility preference tool in the Accessibility section of the GNOME Desktop Preferences.

Once Sticky Keys is enabled a modifier may be "latched" by selecting it. When a modifier is latched it will be applied to the next keystroke and then unlatched once that keystroke is output. For example, to output Shift + A one would select Shift to latch it and then select A. To "lock" a modifier select it twice. When a modifier is locked it will be applied to all following keystrokes until it is unlocked by selecting it again. For example, the output Ctrl + A followed by Ctrl + B followed by Ctrl + C one could perform the following: select Ctrl, select Ctrl again to lock it, select A, select B, select C and select Ctrl to unlock.

listitem.para: Capslock - The "!" (exclamation) symbol indicates that Capslock is "on".
Modifiers such as Shift and Ctrl: The "+" (plus) symbol attached to one of these keys indicates that the key is "latched" or "locked".

sect3.title: Dynamic Keyboards
sect3.para: Dynamic Keyboards are created when GOK is running. An example is a GOK keyboard that is made up of keys based on the menus of the current active application.

sect4.title: Activate
sect4.para: Selecting this button generates a keyboard that displays all windows currently available on a user's system. It is useful for toggling between panels, accessing the GNOME desktop, files, folders and documents, the GOK Main, GOK Settings and so on.

sect4.title: Menus
sect4.para: The Menus button provides access to all menu items in the current application. If, for example, a word processing application is open the GOK might generate a Menus keyboard with the following buttons:

listitem.para: Back - Returns user to GOK - Main
File - Generates a new keyboard displaying all options associated with File
Edit - Generates a new keyboard displaying all options associated with Edit
View - Generates a new keyboard displaying all options associated with View
Search - Generates a new keyboard displaying all options associated with Search
Documents - Generates a new keyboard displaying all options associated with current documents.
Help - Generates a new keyboard displaying all options associated with application's Help feature

sect4.title: Toolbars
sect4.para: If an application has an associated Toolbar, this button will provide access to these items in a dynamically generated onscreen keyboard.

sect4.title: UI Grab
sect4.para: The UI Grab generates a keyboard of all tool buttons associated with an application. For example, if a word processing application is "in focus" the GUI keyboard generated might feature the following toolbar buttons:

listitem.para: Back - Returns user to GOK - Main
Redo - Redo the action that has been reversed by Undo
Paste - Paste or insert text saved on the clipboard elsewhere in document

sect4.title: Text Manipulation
sect4.para: This key (found on the Compose keyboard) launches an onscreen Text Editing keyboard which includes the following buttons:

listitem.para: Word L - cursor moves one space to the left of the last entry
Word R - cursor moves one space to the right of the last entry
S Word L - highlights last entry left of the cursor
S Word R - highlights last entry right of the cursor
S Letter L - highlights letter to the left of the cursor
S Letter R - highlights letter to the right of the cursor
Paste - inserts or "pastes" highlighted text into a document
